Introduction  

Lithium is an effective treatment in bipolar disorder and can be used for acute mania and depression as well as the prevention of depressive and manic episodes.  At therapeutic doses, lithium is associated with a number of adverse effects across multiple organ systems.  Lithium also has a narrow therapeutic index, which elevates the risk of toxicity.  Therefore, patients require routine monitoring of serum lithium levels.

Indications



  • Bipolar disorder:  Lithium is effective as acute treatment of manic and depressive episodes and for maintenance treatment to prevent recurrence of a manic or depressive episode.  It is also effective in reducing the risk of suicide in patients with bipolar disorder.
  • Schizoaffective disorder:  Lithium can be used as an adjunctive agent to an antipsychotic for treatment of major mood episodes in bipolar-type or depressive-type schizoaffective disorder.

Lithium toxicity



Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index (ie, there is little separation between therapeutic and toxic doses).  The therapeutic plasma level ranges between 0.6 to 1.2 mEq/L, but patients may experience lithium toxicity when lithium levels exceed 1.5 mEq/L (

Risk factors



Lithium is renally cleared, in a similar manner to sodium.  Any process that reduces renal perfusion or decreases clearance and glomerular filtration will increase lithium reabsorption, including:



  • Dehydration or volume depletion
  • Renal function impairment (especially in elderly people due to age-related decline in glomerular filtration rate)
  • Concurrent medications:  NSAIDs (not including aspirin), thiazides, ACE inhibitors, tetracyclines, metronidazole
  • Lithium overdose

Clinical presentation



Lithium toxicity presents with a wide variety of gastrointestinal (GI) and neurologic symptoms that range in severity:



  • Mild toxicity:  nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor, ataxia, dizziness, weakness, lethargy
  • Moderate toxicity:  persistent nausea and vomiting, anorexia, blurred vision, confusion, hyperreflexia, fasciculations
  • Severe toxicity:  encephalopathy, myoclonus, seizures, stupor, coma


Serum lithium levels do not always correlate with toxicity severity.  During an acute ingestion, a non-toxic lithium level (eg, <1.5 mEq/L) does not rule out toxicity.  Symptoms can still occur at non-toxic levels, which may continue to rise due to continued absorption.  In these cases, treatment is indicated based on severity of symptoms and not serum lithium levels alone.



On the other hand, even when critical levels (eg, >4 mEq/L) are reached, a patient may be asymptomatic due to the slow distribution of lithium to the central nervous system (CNS).  Severe complications can still occur once lithium reaches the CNS.  Therefore, in cases with critical levels, hemodialysis would be indicated even without severe symptoms.

Management



Lithium toxicity is a medical emergency.  Management includes:



  • Discontinue lithium and initiate intravenous fluids.
  • Obtain and repeat serum lithium level every 4-6 hours until there is clinical improvement or downward trend in serum level.  This is because levels may continue to rise after acute ingestions due to continued reabsorption.
  • If there is an acute ingestion and the patient is awake and asymptomatic, whole bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol should be performed. 
  • Patients with severe toxicity require hemodialysis, as this rapidly removes lithium (a small, charged, non-protein-bound particle).  Indications include:
    • Severe symptoms of toxicity regardless of lithium concentration (eg, coma, seizures, treatment-resistant hypotension)
    • Serum lithium level >4 mEq/L and impaired kidney function
    • Serum lithium level >5 mEq/L

Adverse effects



Multiple organ systems can be affected with therapeutic dosing of lithium.  Many of the adverse effects are mitigated with discontinuation of lithium, though this may result in an increased risk for a recurrent mood episode.

Endocrine



  • Thyroid disease:
    • Goiter (most common):  enlarged thyroid due to compensatory increase in TSH secretion
    • Hypothyroidism:  either overt (high TSH, low free T4/T3) or subclinical (high TSH, normal T4/T3) disease
    • Hyperthyroidism and chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (less common)
  • Hyperparathyroidism due to increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels and hypercalcemia caused by lithium

Renal



  • Lithium-induced arginine vasopressin resistance (
    figure 1
    ):  Arginine vasopressin (AVP) facilitates renal water reabsorption by increasing expression of aquaporin 2 water channel in principal cells of the collecting duct.  Lithium inhibits the function of the aquaporin 2 water channel, leading to impaired renal water reabsorption despite increased secretion of AVP.

    • Results in large volumes of dilute urine (low specific gravity) and hypernatremia
    • Symptoms include polyuria, polydipsia; in more severe cases, confusion and lethargy
    • May resolve after discontinuation of lithium, but permanent impairment can result following years of chronic use
  • Chronic kidney disease:  reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR) can occur with long-term (>10 years) lithium use

Neurologic



Fine action tremors due to lithium are common.  They are typically symmetric and limited to the hands and upper limbs, unlike in lithium toxicity (coarse, irregular tremors that can affect legs).  Tremors are not progressive and often decrease with time without dose change or intervention.  Treatment includes propranolol.

Cardiac



Lithium can cause dysrhythmias (rare) and sinus node dysfunction (depress pacemaking activity of the sinus node).

Skin



Lithium may precipitate or exacerbate acne and psoriasis.

Pregnancy considerations

Teratogenicity



Lithium use during the first trimester increases the risk for cardiac malformations, including Ebstein anomaly, which is the abnormal positioning of the tricuspid valve and atrialization of the right ventricle (

figure 2
).  The absolute risk is small given that Ebstein anomaly is rare in the general population and there is a reduced risk with a lower lithium dose in the first trimester (ie, use minimum effective dose).



Additional adverse effects are associated with lithium use later in pregnancy (eg, neonatal lithium toxicity, preterm delivery).

Renal function during pregnancy



During pregnancy, there is a physiological increase in GFR that can result in a significant decrease in serum lithium levels.  Lithium levels should be monitored closely to guide necessary dose adjustments (ie, may need to increase dose).

Laboratory monitoring



The following labs should be routinely collected prior to initiating as well as throughout the course of lithium treatment:



  • Serum lithium level (trough)
  • Blood urea nitrogen and creatinine
  • Urinalysis
  • Electrolytes, including sodium and calcium levels
  • Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), free T4
  • Electrocardiogram (ECG) should be collected at baseline and repeated annually
  • Pregnancy test in women of childbearing age

Summary



Lithium is an effective medication for bipolar disorder.  Careful evaluation for adverse effects on physical examination and routine laboratory monitoring are crucial due to lithium's narrow therapeutic index and inherent risks to multiple organ systems.
